Fields.DialogueText: Ah, an Italian soldier - listen, I'm trying to find the Soldati-class Destroyer, Carabiniere, do you know where she is?
Si, Capitano, you've found the right woman. I am Carabiniere. I hope to work well with you in the future.
... Huh.
Is something the matter, Capitano? Is it my outfit? I'll have you know it's of the Carabinieri.
Oh, like that auxiliary military unit that's under the RIA? No, it's not the outfit at all! In fact, I think it looks nice, just... are those... handcuffs?
Indeed, Capitano. Though, this is an invention of my own design. If it annoys you, I can put it away.

Fields.MenuText: No, it's fine. I've seen odder.
You made that yourself?
Interesting... a handcuff lasso. Do you catch horses?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I would expect as much! You are a Capitano, and these circumstances we find ourselves in are odd. Still, I will remain vigilant and will assist my namesake if needed. Horses and all.
Si, Capitano. Ci e voluto un po' di tempo. Not too long, though, I could craft one of these things in... say an hour's time? Enough time to help those on patrol and tend to their horses if they need.
I prefer not to catch anything if needed. I am only here to keep the peace, Capitano. After all, a peaceful ship is a peaceful mind. I... do like horses, though. I've seen them rolling about.
You have a thing for horses! Well, I'll be sure to remember that. Is there anything else you'd like me to know? If you don't mind me saying, you have a keen eye, Miss.
Oh, please, Capitano, there's no need for pleasantries; call me "Cara" - it's a bit easier to roll off of the tongue. And grazie - I've been told by my older sister that I'm a bit nosy.
Your older sister... would that happen to be Camicia Nera? She's seen a lot of action since the Morganas have begun to surge.
That does sound like my big sister, always on point, yet never appreciating the finer details. Still, I think she's a wonderful ship. I hope that I can be just as wonderful, Capitano.
First impression wise? Fantastic. I look forward to working with you. Now, how about we get started? Is there anything we need before we head out on a routine journey?
I believe the other staff have already taken care of that. I may not be an actual Carabiniere, I try to replicate their punctuality and quick wits in situations such as this. We have everything.
Excellent. Let's head out—Hm? Oh. Those are some... how did they get out to this dock? Where are the coastal guards?
Hm, it's a mystery. Still, we must deal with these ruffians the best we can. Get on board, Capitano, and please give me your orders once you're settled in.
Top shelf. I'll be sure to do my best.
First impressions, as you said, Capitano. (*giggle*)
@BATTLE
Food? Hygiene products?
There are more of them? Son of a-
Easy, Capitano. Most don't come out of a situation unscathed if they don't use their head. Do you mind if I offer a suggestion?
By all means. How do you suggest we get past these ones?

Hm... Hm... È giusto... È giusto... Hm... Ah. Capitano, the patterns that these Morganas are taking favor starboard and not port. If we were to quickly change direction and attack, they would scatter!
... Impressive. How were you able to figure out their movements in such a short amount of time!?
The patterns of the waves and the way that their guns have consistently fired at our port no matter what we do to maneuver. I will admonish them for thinking that I am weak on one side, however.
Their mistake, our game. Full speed to their port!
After this, I feel some tea would be in order.
@BATTLE
Troublemakers out. Well done, Cara! I wouldn't have picked up on that for a while.
It's all about the details, Capitano. Viva Italia. (*schwing*)

Fields.MenuText: Excuse me, is that a sword?
Such pretty silver...
A sword, too? What else do you have under that cloak?

Fields.DialogueText: This is a saber, Capitano. It's a standard for the Carabiniere. I carry it around for close quarters should we be attacked on deck or if this form of mine needs to join the fighting. Lovely, no?
Thank you, Capitano. I polish it daily along with my rifle. After all, any self-respecting soldier should make sure their equipment is well taken care of.
Would you believe more handcuffs? (*giggle*) Apologies, Capitano, I did not mean to scare you. You never know when you'll need a sword.
It's possibly one of the most high-quality swords I've seen. I just didn't know officers still carried swords when combat knives and bayonets exist.
I heard there was an ally among the British who has been spotted using a sword and a bow and arrow, so, anything is possible, no?
Point taken. Ah, I'm a bit tired... Could you please brew tea for two? I think I could use that and some music.
Of course, Capitano. My thoughts were on the same thing. Decompression is just as important as defense.
It's a part of the uniform, as well. A Carabiniere isn't one without it.
Eh? Cara? Why are you in here?
Huph! O-Oh, Capitano, good afternoon - I was j-just sitting down to get some food.
... Are you shivering?
O-Oh, no, Capitano. I'm just a bit chilly is all. Nothing wrong!

Fields.MenuText: Why do I smell... cigarette smoke?
Kind of... ashy in here.
Don't try to bluff me, Cara.

Fields.DialogueText: Some of the soldiers wanted to smoke outside, and then more joined in after a bit. I-I don't allow smoking inside my walls, a-at least, not any more I don't.
Oh, I apologize! That must be my odor, I've been told to fix it up. I've also been telling the engineers to use better coal as well, j-just so that I don't smell like an ashtray! I-I...
Haha... I probably was obvious. It wouldn't take Poirot or, even Watson to sniff me out, wouldn't it? I'm sorry, Capitano. I'm just going through some withdrawl.
Be easy on yourself, Cara. Do you need me to go out and tell them to stop smoking?
N-No, Capitano, that won't be necessary. I must share this space, too. I apologize, this must be so unsightly.
Nonsense, Cara. If you're trying to quit something that's bad for you, I'd be glad to help. It's my duty as a Captain, after all.
I understand that... it's just, you would probably like a ship that can take care of herself, no? Something that would let you focus on what's important.
The Morganas are important, but what's important to me as a Captain is the crew and the ship itself, you, Cara. If you need help with this, I would be glad to.
What would you suggest, Capitano?
I don't have much experience with quitting myself, but I want to learn with you, Cara. I promise, I'll do my best.
Hm! That's all I ever ask of you and of my crew, Capitano. R-Right now it's incredibly difficult, however.
I can go outside and tell them to stop, I mean it, I will. Or, we can go somewhere else?
I-I think maybe that would solve something... Hm? What's that smell? It doesn't smell like smoke...
Ack! Candlewax... There's a Morgana incoming! I need to get to the bridge!
I'll be right behind you, Capitano. Grazie.
@BATTLE
Giorgio, why do you have alcohol out here?
I'm just drinking out here, it's that kind of day. Why?
Giorgio... as per regulations of this ship, you aren't allowed to drink alcohol unless if you are in the mess hall. Please put it away, or I'll have to confiscate it.
Come on, Carabiniere, lay off. I'm having a rough day.
Please, Giorgio. I am the ship, but I'm also a rule enforcer. I don't want to confiscate that.
Well you can just mind your own business and then I'll keep drink—
It's the law here, Giorgio. I am being firm. Please.
For the love of—To hell with you. Fine. I'll follow your rules.
Hmmm... (*Sigh*)

Fields.MenuText: Rule breakers, huh?
Well handled, Cara.
He realizes that he can just talk to his squadron, right?

Fields.DialogueText: He didn't do it on purpose, but there are better ways to cope with that, and ones that don't involve endangering people on the ship. I apologize, Capitano, our crew is better, I promise.
Did you think so, Capitano? I apologize for Giorgio. It's a new policy we're rolling out on here. I feel our soldiers should be professional, it's part of the duty to the country and world.
I don't know whether or not he does. Regardless, I apologize for his behavior, Capitano. I firmly believe that drinking is fine, but drinking out on the ship when it's firmly stated in the rules...
I think you were just fine, Cara. You were within reason, calm, and collected. Though, I think I'll be the one to talk with Giorgio later, I understand a bit about his problems. Everyone has them.
I wish there was a way to solve them that didn't involve ruining the harmony of the ship. Though, I suppose that's what problems create in the first place.
Everyone has problems, but nobody can just outright solve them. Sometimes it takes multiple people, or even the person themselves to figure it out. I do agree, though, harmony is—E-Eh!? Cara!?
Oof! N-No, Captain, I'm all right. It would appear someone else has problems that they'd like to express.
There are now, are there? Well, how about we show them just how we deal with them?
Rightly so, Capitano.
@BATTLE
All we have to do is take care of these last Morganas, and we'll be home free!
@BATTLE
Well, that took care of everything for now. Time to take a break.
Perfect. This gives me some time to read, too.
The Mysterious Affair At Styles? That's Agatha Christie! Do you like mystery novels, Cara?
I love reading mysteries, Capitano - it helps to build my skills. Though, if you ask me, I think Poirot is more entertaining than Marple.

Fields.MenuText: What would you say your favorite Christie book is?
No wonder you're so level-headed!
You ever thought about writing your own?

Fields.DialogueText: I think that has to got to be The Murder of Roger Ackroyd. It relies on contextual clues heavily - perfect for me to pick apart.
Hahaha! I suppose when you train your logical thinking skills for that long, you would have to be; but in all seriousness, Capitano, I am no different than any other Belle.
Several times - though, for now, I believe my place is firmly as a soldier. Perhaps after the war is over? A good mystery is one that can be written, sure, but it needs to be picked apart as well.
It's good to have someone around that can get to the root of problems. I'm surprised more people haven't worked with you yet!
Sister says it's because I'm too nosy. I will give her that: I cannot tell a lie, but I can tell when someone is, usually. According to my sister, this can come off as off-putting.
Wanting to tell the truth isn't off-putting, Cara - though I don't think you have to waste time calling out every white lie spoken onboard.
"Don't say it straight away"... Er, Capitano?
Yes, Cara?
If it's not too much trouble to ask, after I finish reading two chapters, could you please teach me how to "build up" to the time when I do say the truth?
Maybe two chapters will give me time to figure out how to say what I mean more clearly. But, for the record, I'm always happy to help.
Capitano... Thank you! Now, onto the mystery at hand...
I think I'll actually go grab a book myself. Should I start with The Mysterious Affair At Styles?
Unfortunately, this is my only copy. However, there's a copy of The Secret Adversary on my bookshelf. It's not the same series as Poirot, but it's a good place to start! I'll help you find it!
I just know how to get to the heart of things.
"White lie?" Capitano, the truth is the truth, and we're all better off if it's made as plain as can be. We need to trust each other in war!
Oh, yeah! I'm just saying... you shouldn't go right for the throat straight away. Do you know what I mean?
Hm? Visitors?
Si, Capitano. These are members of some new anti-Morgana group, with a German advisor; they've requested the opportunity to come and inspect us. Is that all right?
It's fine - send them in.
Good afternoon, Kapitän. Thank you for having us on the Carabiniere. I am Christoph, Oberscharführer, Waffen-SS. These are my associates.
Henri, with the Légion des volontaires français contre le Morganisme. Was part of the Marine Nationale. I'm originally from Strasbourg.
You can call me Pepe! I was also part of the French Navy before I switched sides.
Hmmm...

Fields.MenuText: Something wrong, Cara?
(Turncoats, eh? I don't like it either.)
(*Give Carabinieri a nod.*)

Fields.DialogueText: N-Nothing, Capitano. (I just wasn't expecting the officers from France to be so proud of their turning tail.) It's very nice to meet all of you!
(It... makes me feel sad.) Pleasure to meet all of you! Welcome, what brings you here to inspect!?
(Oh, thank goodness, Capitano. You feel it, too?) It's good to meet all of you. Thank you for coming!
Thank you for the warm welcome, Miss Carabiniere. We've come here mostly to talk with Il Duce's men, but they asked us to take a look around you, they're busy with other things. I hope we aren't-
No, no! You are completely fine to walk around here, but please treat my crew with respect, sir. Oh, and no alcohol except for in the mess hall. That's about it.
Kapital! Well, excuse us. We will begin our examination. We promise not to go too overboard! Pfft... overboard! Hahahaha! Oh... Excuse us, please.
I... didn't like that, Capitano. I know they're our allies, and I'm grateful to have them, but...
I swear, it's always the SS that rub people the wrong way. I think that might be for good reason. Either way, they're our guests.
I-I just think I have the jitters, Capitano. Something about that was... H-Hmph. I can't stand people who would just give away their country like that!
Ergh! I'm so frustrated!
Sounds like you need to blow off some steam. How about we go Morgana hunting?
W-whatever it takes!
@BATTLE
... We are?
Ja, Kapitän. And you yourself have led the way!
You've shown the world that we have to rise above our problems with one another to fight these terrible invaders! That the British and the French should join with Germany - and Italy, of course!
All in the name of a common front against the Nixen, ja?
... Huh.
Yeah, we have international crew, sure, but nobody's been asked to turn over their own flags, so to speak - that's new to me.
"Switched sides?"
My friend here misspoke, I think. It's true that the Reich is helping the people of France who want to fight our common enemy.
D-Don't let that get in the way of a good time though, we're all friends here!
We even have special credentials with the SS!
To think we'd be on patrol out here. Montorosse is a little too nice, don't you think?
Well, it is part of our patrol area! Besides, watching the skyline and seeing everyone have fun is worth it's own. Oh! Look at those bambini!
They look like they're having the time of their lives. Do you like kids, Cara?
They'll propel Italia into a future neither you or I could possibly imagine. Of course, they have a lot to learn.

Fields.MenuText: Much like myself.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, come now, Capitano. You're not a child!

Fields.MenuText: Kids are a handful...

Fields.DialogueText: Aren't they? Little bundles of joy that always ask too many questions and annoy you at every end...

Fields.MenuText: Italy's spirit, eh?

Fields.DialogueText: The spirit of Italia rests within her people and the children. Ask questions, find answers, and always find a better way. Respect the tradition, but embrace the future, do you understand, Capitano?
That's... actually a really good way to think about life, however, I think people should also look at the answers part of it. I mean, look at those children. What is their answer to having fun?
Fuhahaha! You've got a good point, Capitano. You know, I think that's the answer that evades people the most when they're older. At least, that's what I hear among our soldiers.
Please don't tell me how much time has passed, Cara. I'm going to get gray hairs.
Oh come now, Capitano. You don't look that old! Besides, gray hairs are a mark of a maturity.
Oh, sure they are. Just like how dents in a battleship are mark it as experienced.
H-Hey... Ehi adesso! Pfft... Hahahahaha! Never let it be said, you don't have humor, Capitano—E-Eh? Wait, why are the children swimming further out? D-Do they want to meet us?
Aw, son of a bitch! Where is the... Hold on! Binoculars... Ah! Damn it! Morganas are coming in and they're already influencing the area!
Are they!? Are we the only ship around!? Where are the others!?
I don't know, but they're certainly not here! Damn, they're already going out too far! We need to get to them, right away!
A rescue mission, count me in. I'm with you, Capitano. I'll rescue the future before those Morganas even fire a salvo!
That's what I like to hear! Full speed!
@BATTLE
You are right about learning, though - I think that's what makes life interesting, always asking questions and finding answers.
... Yet it's that same curiosity that serves us well in adulthood. The need to understand the causes and nature of our struggles.
Does Camicia Nera have any suggestions for properly Fascist fun?
Sorry. That probably crossed a line or three. It's just been a long war, I guess.
Oh, I'm sure. You've been fighting since the very first day, haven't you? That's-
When you think about it, Poirot feels like a hard boiled egg compared to the sort of sunny-side up hero you'd find in comic books.
I think that's what makes him so charming. A bit of darkening on the meat, you know?
Uwaahhhh!!! H-Horrible!!!
Signore Pepe? What brings you into the Capitano's Quarters? You look awfully pale.
A-Ah, Miss Carabiniere, Captain, I need your help! M-My Heart has been stolen!

Fields.MenuText: Ah, I remember the first time I fell in love.
Your heart looks fine to me, Mr. Pepe.
Some kind of medal?

Fields.DialogueText: Was it as romantic as you thought it would be, Capitano? Ah, I think I should get some more romance novels in my collect—

Indeed. From what I can tell, you don't have any rashes or blemishes. Have you not been getting enough sunlight? I know that it's bad for the skin if you don't get enough—Or, did you lose something important?
Could be perhaps a play on the Tell-Tale Heart. I really loved that short story, though, I'm more of someone who took the Monkey's Paw as more of a lesson. ... Wait, Signore, did you lose something?
Yes, yes, yes I have! The Heart isn't something metaphorical, It's a badge! The Coeur de Faucon!
Sounds like quite the important badge - do you think you may have misplaced it, Signore? Where was the last time you had it?
I-I don't know! Please, both of you have to help me! I-If I don't get that back, Christoph will have my head! That badge is extremely important... Oh, what am I going to do?
(This guy is so corny, I'd swear I was in Iowa.)
(That's mean, Capitano...) Hmm... If you would like, I can search around to see if I can find it. You all leave in two weeks, right? That should give us plenty of time.
Eh, I don't see why not. Sure. We'll help you find it, Pepe.
You will!? Oh thank you, thank you, thank you! I-I last had it in the engine room and I... *bzzt*! Ahhhh... H-Herr Christoph is calling for me, I-I need to go!
... What an absolute mess of a man.
Hmhmhm! You're a bit of a feisty one, Capitano. Me, personally, I would prefer if we could get this solved. It might look bad on us if we can't find it.
That's true. I just, thought you didn't want to help—
A-Another time, Capitano. I don't feel comfortable talking about it now.
Understandable. I'm sorry I overstep—Ah!? (*Explosion*) Looks like we've got bigger problems than a mystery...
I wouldn't say that! Maybe the Morganas know exactly where the badge is... let's see what they know!
@BATTLE
E-Eh, I think Mr. Pepe is talking about something else. Did you lose something important?
I-I need it for both the Légion and the Waffen-SS! Otherwise th-there are places I just can't go!
Now, he said the engine room, but according to the procession, they said they started out here on the bridge.
When retracing steps and trying to figure something out, you always have to go to the beginning. It's the same with a book, go to the contents, then to the prologue.
Where do you think the delegation came from, then?
Hm... Retracing the memory of that day... Ah. I remember them entering from port. Once they got on port, then they went immediately to the bridge. I never felt them anywhere else before that.
No stops?
None. They came right this way and then went down to the engine room, then they waltzed back around and met us. They didn't stop anywhere on the way there, either. It means that—A-Ah...
Eh? Cara? Is everything all right?
S-Si, Capitano, I-I'm fine.

Fields.MenuText: Why start lying now? You're terrible!
Cara. Look at me. What's wrong?
(*Sniff*) Is someone... smoking?

Fields.DialogueText: I-I think they are, Captiano. That's not illegal on the s-ship, but to do it right outside the bridge is a bit inconsiderate. I-I should give them a stern talking to... I-I... I'm sorry... I need...
Nothing! Nothing is wrong, Capitano. Please! W-We have a mystery to solve... I-I'm sorry for yelling, I just... Guh... I need to... sit down...
Stai zitto! Stai! Zitto! You don't know when or where I've been lying, never mind started! How dare you think you know me!? Don't come at me with... with...!
Hey! Hey! Cara... Damn it. I know it's every soldier's right to smoke, but if it does this to my Belle—
I'm sorry, Capitano, you shouldn't be worrying about me. I-I am a soldier first, a ship.
Stai zitto. Be quiet. I won't hear you talk about yourself that way, not when you've already taken up this job with Pepe.
Capitano...
Breaking habits is hard - but you don't have to do it alone. I'll be with you. I promise.
Y-Yes... I'm sorry for causing you trouble, Capitano. I—
You can make up for it by showing me how good of a shot you are. We've got company, from the look of things. Where the hell are communications?
... Dannazione. They're on their smoke break. Capitano, if you'd be all right with—
Way ahead of you. Let's get that blowout and then get back on the case.
@BATTLE
Damned things, I-I'd even smoke one of those cheap Marlboros!
A-Augh. C-Capitano, I'm sorry. Stupid... cigar smoke...
I've really forgotten how big the engine room can feel in a woken Belle.
I'm rather proud of it. It's a nice area once you get to know the place. Neat, well-maintained, and the crew here knows a thing or two about nautical travel, so there's always a good source for info.

Fields.MenuText: What about leads?
Maybe they should be the navigators - do they smoke?
They sound more like officers.

Fields.DialogueText: They have plenty of them, from gossip, games, and booze to war opinions, editorials, and one of them's an artist.
Unfortunately, they do. Though, when you're down in the part of the ship that's the first to flood and survival is almost a crooked sale, I don't blame them. They talk like grizzled veterans.
I heard one of them's going to be promoted to an officer soon, and he's going to take some time to train the younger staff down here before he does.
Speaking of talking, I sort of had a question about this Coeur. Why's it so important, other than letting Pepe "do things?" I heard it let him pass areas. Also, what does it look like?
The Coeur de Faucon is meant to be a rare honor, Capitano. The Legion has started handing it out to those who have shown exceptional skill - though I hear they're actually made in Germany.
So we're talking about exceptional skill in betrayal?
It can function as that as well. I got the details from Christoph, who seemed curious as to how I knew about it. I may not be a good liar, but you were right, Capitano: the pleasantries come first.
Atta girl. So what else can it function as?
... That explains why Christoph is here. But Pepe's a few cards short of a deck.
He wasn't when he and Henri sold out an important French supply depot in Alsazia.
That's... despicable. How could anybody do that!? How did you find that out?
As you said, Capitano, you can wait on the truth a bit. Christoph was eager to tell me about his new protege. I think he's placed his faith in the wrong person.
It looks like a falcon?
A tough nut, you'd think it would look like the silver falcons they wear on their uniforms. No.
Then it makes you wonder, how did Pepe miss it?
That's what I'd like to find out—W-Woah!
Huph! Got you.
N-Nice catch, Capitano. Those Morganas seem to have too good timing lately.
@BATTLE
You could find out anything if you stayed down here for long enough. Sometimes I listen in...
From what I've heard, he's tough on the outside, soft on the inside.
Simply put, it's serving as a kind of passport. The French don't officially recognize it, outside of certain regions, but German ports and naval vessels are supposed to...
... and apparently Roma will accept it as identification as well.
But it's the Waffen-SS that seem most involved in the project, whether they like it or not.
There were nearly forty deaths, and a nearby Jewish community just vanished. The Germans gained a factory, "to protect it from the Morganas."
As for the Coeur du Faucon itself, it's exactly what it sounds like.
This one is gold, and has six wings as opposed to just two. It also has a special red sash coming from the tailfeathers; it's hard to miss.
Maybe "big" isn't the right word. Grand, maybe?
They were part of a delegation from the Marine Nationale tasked with evaluating defenses against Morganas along the Rhine.
And apparently they perceived an "immediate threat" in late January and appealed for Wehrmacht forces to establish a beachhead in French territory for the common defense.
Pepe and Henri were drummed out of the Marine Nationale, but they immediately went on to start this Legione of theirs.
But they haven't gotten past us yet.
And they won't, Capitano!
Wasn't expecting Porta del Borgo to be this nice. This is like something out of a film.
... Hmmm... Those big manes...
Shops, salons, nice roads, people without a care in the world, it's a nice change from gunfire. Hm? Hey! Look over there! I didn't know the Italian Police rode horseback!
They're so lovely...
Cara?
What I wouldn't give to be able to ride horseback again, oh, it was so much fun when I got the chance to. Prancing around, feeling the wind through your hair, the lovely sun—
Are you in there, Cara? I didn't know you liked horseback riding?
Aaap! C-Capitano, I'm sorry, I got lost in thought. Y-Yes, I do love horses.

Fields.MenuText: You'd probably be a great rider.
Would you like me to get you one for the ship?
Beautiful. A reliable horse is like a well-oiled motorcycle.

Fields.DialogueText: Aren't they, though? If you ask me, a horse can handle rougher terrain than one of those mechanized serpents. They're all muscle and built tough, and they're really affectionate. Ah... a dream.
Sorry, Capitano. That wouldn't be fair to the crew and probably violates a few seafaring laws. Besides, I think it's better to dream. One day, when we find a way to go further out, I'd love to ride.
I think I would as well. I have plenty of horse riding books in my collection and have ridden once twice. They're so strong and reliable! I wish I could ride them more often - but a lady can dream...
You could ride if you really wanted to. We just have to get the paperwork going.
Capitano, that's incredibly sweet, but you don't have to bend your neck for—
No, really, we can get one for the ship. After all, Texas has one. You've probably met her before, USS Texas. Nice girl. She rides that horse on deck like nobody's business, and she lives it up.
Cara? Are you all right?
Cara?
I-I'm sorry, Capitano, I... I feel I just—Oh! Look at that. Morganas to west!
Good eye. Let's get to the bridge and sort this out.
I think I could use something to get my aggression out.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Actually, she might be able to put us in touch with somebody to look after the horse too. She's probably got a team.

Fields.DialogueText: Bluebonnet's the name. Beautiful animal. Robot. Whatever.
Just my luck. I try to sit down to do my notes and the alarm is ringing. I hope Cara is all right...
Capitano! ... Sorry about the door! We need to hurry, the Morganas are closing in on the port!
So they think they can just walk by us, huh? Obviously they've never seen a Carabiniere.
Per l'Italia! My honor!
@BATTLE
Now that that's over with... what's the scoop?
You're going to love this one. I went and talked with the engine room folks. I got a lead. Turns out we were on the right path, they did see something down there. Something important.

Fields.MenuText: Did they finally stop smoking?
Did we find any redeeming qualities about Pepe?
Were they tough on you?

Fields.DialogueText: I wish they did, but they haven't. If anything, they've become real chain smokers. If I didn't know any better, I'd say half of them had ashtrays for lungs.
C-Capitano! That's incredibly rude..! ... I did not hear much of Pepe from them, other than he wasn't the one wearing the badge. I will admit, we did have a laugh at Pepe's expense...
No, we have a nice relationship, actually. They call me "piccola" despite the fact that I'm 190cm. Feels kind of odd, but as long as everyone's happy.
Sounds pretty eventful. So, what did you figure out?

The badge was spotted yesterday as a matter of fact. A fading golden glow in the engine room. They didn't see who it was, but they were heading in a certain direction. It sounded like a start to a chase.
And did it turn into one?
I asked them where they thought they saw the gleaming object was heading in. They asked me if I was crazy, sure, you'd have to be pretty crazy to draw a lead from something like that.
I take it you did find a lead, then? Where did it go?
Giorgio had an answer for that one. He said he saw a gold gleam through one of the windows outside. It was heading in the direction of the mess hall. I think our culprit was hungry.
So, the mess hall, next? Looks like we've got a potential lead if I ever saw one. Actually... that makes our job both easier and harder.
Why, Capitano?
Because while the culprit is most likely on this ship... our suspect list is about 50. 60 if you count the delegation, not including Pepe, Christoph, and Henri.
Guess we'll have to whittle it down, then. I'll head to the mess hall soon. I would like to read more of Styles.
I would, too. Bring that book here. Let's read together.
Hehehe! Glad to see you so excited, Capitano! All right, so, Chapter 4...
There's a different air here when everyone's gone. It's almost... peaceful.
That's the mess for you. It's a watering hole at its core, a place for everyone to relax and to talk about the days gone by in this wild world of ours—A brief respite in the madness.
War. No matter which way you try to sell it, rebrand it, or repack it—It's all the same. Let's start looking for clues.
Capital. Where do you think we should start?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe in the galley? Bound to be something in there.
Those tables look odd.
Do you want to talk it over some wine?

Fields.DialogueText: Are you sure you're not just hungry, Capitano? If you want, I could make you something? Belles may not need to eat, but I love eating at least once a day.
Did they forget to clean up afterwards? I've never seen such disarray... I'm not going to sit here and tolerate it, either. I'll have to give whoever was last in here a talking to...
It's far too early in the day to be thinking about that, Capitano. Wine is like the free flowing river that's only talked about in la Bibbia, you drink a few sips and you start telling truths.
It's weird to think that we're supposed to be culling the Morganas and yet here we are, trying to solve a mystery. Still, I wouldn't mind doing it if it's with you, Cara.
Likewise, Capitano. You've been a good sport about this!
Sure, but it doesn't look too promising. ... (They left a bunch of ingredients out. Were they prepping for dinner? I thought dinner was already made?)
Oh, Capitano! I found something! Check this out.
Hm. I'll hang on to this. Did you find anything else of value? I'll keep searching around here for now.
Just some stuff they left out: anchovies, tomatoes. Bread that's probably halfway to stale. I don't know what you could do with—
Hohoh~ We're going to eat good tonight, Capitano. That sounds like just the right ingredients to make bagnun - come, I'll show you how to make it.
You know how to cook?
It's a requirement for Carabiniere. ... Just kidding! I wanted to learn how to cook after I was loaned a cookbook by big sis. Now, what are we going to do for gra-
Oof! Ow... Nice catch, Cara. Did you... feel that?
I sure did. Perhaps the bagnun will be sweeter after I work up an appetite with these Morganas? Let's find out.
@BATTLE
Now, let's start with these tables. I wager there something we could find here. When examining tables, always start with the margins. Oh, could you check the galley?
*BOOM*
A scrunched-up note? I think that may officially constitute a clue. What does it say?
It's French. Just... "Be proud of yourself! Remember M."
Is it a code?
There's no way to know - not yet. And what do you make of this smudge?
It's dark, whatever it is. Doesn't look like blood, though.
Either way, I don't think we'll find clues there.
I heard rifle cracking earlier, Cara, are you all right... what are you up to?

Oh, Buon giorno, Capitano. I'm just cleaning my rifle and doing some target practice. Did you know that most officers know how to take their own rifle apart? I can assemble mine in about five seconds.

Fields.MenuText: You do target practice in your own room?
Isn't this a bit dangerous, Cara?
Five seconds!?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, it's perfectly safe, Capitano. The target over there will absorb any blanks I shoot at it, and I won't have to worry about ricocheting at all. After all, an ounce of prevention!
Normally, it would be, but I had the designers at a military shooting range in Rome create a nul-ricochet target and frame. I could shoot off of any wall in here and the bullet would stop.
If you'd like me to demonstrate, I very well could. I'd have this thing apart, unloaded, and then in reverse in about five seconds.
Your attention to detail never stops amazing me, Cara. You'd make a great sniper if you were ever an infantry woman.
I'm more of a... frontliner, Capitano. Everyone else has said that I'd be a great sniper, even for a crackshot like me, but I prefer being up front. Something about being in the back is just... um...
I'm sorry, did I make you uncomfortable? I didn't mean to?
No, no! Capitano, you're fine. I just had some memories—A-Anyway, I have something that may interest you. I analyzed the stain on the note we found.
Oh, what did you find?
Chocolate. Intriguing, but unlikely to be decisive.
The plot thickens... but at least that narrows down our suspects. Who do you think it could be?
We would have to check the ledger in the mess hall to even begin whittling down the suspects, and since this ship is usually stocked with upwards of 100 people, it would take a while to get to it.
You know it! ... Hey, what were you shooting at, anyway? I can see a picture.
Oh, I just found a random newspaper clipping while were at Gilio, nothing too special.
Hey... that looks a lot like Tex—
C-Capitano! I feel... a presence.
Oh, how convenient—Oof! That was a salvo... Maybe I'm just over thinking it, let's roll.
(Ah, thank the lord in heaven.)
@BATTLE
I'd be able to fire with no problems - no ricochet either, thanks to how this room's designed.
Still, I'm up for it if you are!
Let's start with the basics - given the use of French and the choice of targets, we must explore the possibility that our perpetrator is one of our recent guests. There were 20 commission members...
Let's see... costs, letters from home, letters from base, letters from Roma... Hm? This one has Camicia Nera's name on it? ... Cara! This is for you!
Oh. Big Sis has decided to write me, eh? I wonder what she has to say?

Fields.MenuText: Hopefully positive things.
I'll bet the letter smells like an ashtray.
Do you write each other often?

Fields.DialogueText: It depends on the day, really. Sometimes Nera's letters range from lurid images of smoking and alcohol to full on rants against whichever Morgana she's fighting. She's quite a card.
You'd think! The truth is that she gives them all a hit of this peach fragrance. I'm not sure how she gets it, but I'm appreciative of what lengths she goes to to make the letter nice.
Si - we do, actually. Sis says that I'm to write her one letter a month, or else she'll come here and chew me out! If you ask me though, I think she's just... different like me, you know?
Deep down she's kind of a softy, huh? I wouldn't have guessed.
Hm... Hm... Hm... I'll have to pen another letter as soon as I can. Feh! Her calling me "La Benemerita" again - I wish she'd stop with that. I'm not that lucky.
Does your sister tease you a lot? I know about the other Belles and how you feel about them, but-
Oh, no, Capitano, it's all right. Cami just likes to tease is all. It's like you said, those other Belles just don't understand me well... not like you, of course. I just wish they'd... E-Excuse me.
Cara... you know what I told you about being honest?
R-Right, I'm sorry, Capitano. It's hard not to let them get to you, but... I just wish they'd give me... O-Oh, I'm sorry. I'm not supposed to be like this—
You're a Belle, Cara. Listen to me. You are a product of humanity's spirit, you may be the spirit of the ship, but you are a being who can think, walk, and talk.
It's all rank and file, Capitano. T-They think I'm some kind of wind-up soldier, and-
You are more than your namesake. You're agreeable, have a high aptitude for detail, and are pleasant to be around. You don't have to change for them.
Capitano...
I mean it. They can do their gossip all they want, but they'll never be you, and they'll never know who you are, Cara.
... Cami's words in this letter are happy to me, but the other Belles have been talking behind my back.
Well, let them stew in their notions. Meanwhile, you've got a case to solve, people to save, and at the end of the day, Cara; you're you. Nobody can take that from—
Capitano... there's a presence.
Of all the g—
Please don't take the lord's name in vain. ... I understand your frustration, though. Let's continue this later, huh? Right now, we've got to take care of this.
Right away. Oh, and, Cara?
Yes, Capitano?
They won't know and they sure as hell don't. After this, we'll talk more about it, and then you can draft the letter!
@BATTLE
Get me a status report, people! And if you're not actually on fire, I expect you to keep your wits about you.
The Capitano's right! We may have been cut off from the fleet, but we're still in this.
How're you holding up, Cara?
Bene, bene. Capitano, if we just—
Oh, hell. Brace for impact!
Capitano, let me. Hm! *Rustle*

Fields.MenuText: C-Cara... you're hugging me?
Uh-! ... Cara, are you—
... You don't need to do that.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course I am, Capitano. You need to calm down. Come on, ignore what's in front of you for a few seconds and breathe. Don't worry, I know where my enemies are. Right now, you need to breathe.
Yes I am, Capitano. Please, just relax your muscles a bit. I'm still here, and I'm not going anywhere any time soon. It's going to be all right. We're in this together, Capitano—I promise you.
And you don't need to worry, Capitano. Relax your muscles, and take a few deep breaths. We'll get out of this together, I promise. I'm your partner, you're mine.
... Okay, you may now consider me braced for impact.
Focus, Capitano. The level-headed strategist wins the day.
Right. So. We're surrounded.
My hull is big, Capitano, but my courage is bigger. We need to make an opening. That Morgana ahead of us is too preoccupied with an auxiliary ship. We need to get through her first. Are you with me?
Heh. By all means.
"By all means?" I'm going to have to ask you to forgive me being a little crass, but—Sound off like you've got a pair!
Good, because I want to discuss some clues I found after this. Full speed ahead!
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
*BOOM*
The rest of you, stop staring and get back to work!

Fields.MenuText: Yes, ma'am! Right away!
I like your spirit - but I'm still your superior officer.
... Care to rephrase that?

Fields.DialogueText: *ahem* Mi dispiace, Capitano.
Now, once we clear out the Morganas ahead of us, we'll have some breathing room. Once we do that, we can loop back around and get the others. Are you with me?
Absolutely.
One more Morgana to go, Capitano? Can you keep up?
Talk is cheap. Let me show you!
@BATTLE
Good show, Capitano. That takes care of that handily. I really like what you did with the salvos, too. They walked right into it!

Fields.MenuText: You were the brains, Cara.
Assissted by a beautiful soldier.
A detective always needs a sidekick, don't they?

Fields.DialogueText: Two heads are better than one, Capitano. A ship requires a crew and Captain. I'm just here to help you and likewise, you're here to help me. We're a team, remember? I wouldn't have it any other way.
B-Beautiful? I would say I'm dignified, but, beautiful? No, Capitano. You know what Big Sis says, I'm a doll.
You are NOT a sidekick, Capitano. You're a detective yourself, analyzing evidence, and being impartial when needed. A lot of people would kill to have somebody like that! You and I? We're a team.
I'm glad to be with you, Cara. You did well. ... Oh, that's right, what was the clue you figured out?
Oh, that's right! Here. This is the ledger for the mess hall on the day that Pepe said the Coeur was misplaced. Right off the bat, do you notice anything about it?
Yes, I do. It's the coalition. They all ate at the same time on the same day and only for one meal.
You're part right, Capitano, but there's something missing about that. You see, look down here: three of them ate later.
Look what they ordered, too. They didn't ask for anything special, even though guests on the Carabiniere are usually treated to stuff like that. ... I don't think it relates that much, but-
No, no, Capitano. That's a clue indeed. Now, we just need to ask the chefs about what they saw, or anyone else in that general area. I think we're narrowing it down.
Guess that means I'm a regular Dick Tracy.
Dick Tracy? Who's that, Capitano?
A detective story comic. If you'd like, I could show you a couple.
B-By all means! I've been meaning to add some new stuff to my collection. We'll investigate the mess hall later!
S-Still, thank you for that; but you should know, a team is two. I couldn't have done it without you.
Now, I'm no esperta on when human beings stuff your faces, but why not eat in the company of your people?
Man, this soup is great. Thanks for making it, Cara.
I was a bit hungry, too. No problem, Capitano.
Heya, Carabiniere.
Giorgio! What brings you to the mess hall? Me and Capitano eat a little bit later.
I know, I just wanted to tell you something about the case. You told me you were trying to find out stuff about the delegation here in the mess.
Something here we should be looking at?
No, but I did see a delegation member yesterday with a badge that looks an awful lot like the badge you two are looking for.
What!? What did he look like? Was it a him?
I think so - but I didn't really get a good look. He was leaving with it as I came in and I didn't want to confront 'im.
I'll write that down... do you have anything else to report, Giorgio?
No, ma'am. I'm going on a smoke break at the docks. Capitano told me to take it easy on you and I think I should. See you both around.
Capitano...

Fields.MenuText: See? All I had to do was ask.
Guess I've got the sticky fingers.
Cara, you're trying hard. I can help out, too.

Fields.DialogueText: C-Capitano... That's wonderful. I-I know it isn't fair to the crew, but if they're all willing to do it away from me, then I... I guess we both can learn a lot, still. I- E-Excuse me... *sniff*
Pfft... Hahahahahaha! Aha... hahahaha! Oh, that's horrible, Capitano! Come on! T-Thank you... I seriously can't find any other words to say other than thank you. I-I'm...
C-Capitano... Oh no... Please, please don't do this to me, I can't handle it right now. I-I need to... *sniff* I need to...

Fields.MenuText: (Open your arms for Cara.)

Fields.DialogueText: Capitano..! T-Thank you.
Of course, Cara. We're a team. We're both learning more as we go on.
Hmmm... I-It's just that, Big Sis keeps telling me about them, and...
One step at a time. That's how it is—
Capitano... Morganas are...
Good timing as usual. All right, let's do this thing. If you want hugs afterward, I wouldn't mind giving them.
I-I would like that a lot, actually...
@BATTLE
He had black hair - oh, and a little scar on the back of his shoulder. I saw it when he was scratching his neck.
I didn't think Isola Sacra would be having this much trouble. Where are the other Belles?
Slacking off, it looks like. Time for this "doll" to take care of business. Are you with me, Capitano?
Yes, ma'am. Let's roll.
@BATTLE
Well, they should be able to handle the rest from here. Sad to see that Italy's in this state.
It... wasn't always like this, Capitano. Even with Il Duce in power now, t-things could be a lot better.
I agree. At least the Carabinieri are on the patrol and we've got a good line of defense here... when they're not off somewhere else.
About the Carabinieri... y-yes, they're doing a good job. M-Mhm.

Fields.MenuText: Cara...
You're still a horrible liar, Cara.
Is something wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: Please don't say that to me like that. I-I can't talk about w-what's on my mind. You told me it's better to hold it in until you really trust the other person or you think they need to hear it, and-
I need to w-work on it... Let me assure you, Capitano. N-Nothing's wrong with me. I just need to take a few minutes to breathe. Thinking about the Carabinieri is... it's hard. It really is.
N-No...! G-Guh... Curse it, I can't say everything's fine when you give me that look. I'm sorry, Capitano. I just have a lot of things on my mind right now, especially about... them.
Cara, it's just us here on the bridge. You can trust me. I promise you. Like you said, emotions are normal. You need to get them out.
I-I don't... Hmmm..! I don't like the current Carabinieri. I can't speak on Il Duce, but I do have a lot of problems with how they're acting right now. It breaks my heart.
What's with them?
What's with them!? They're being twisted, Capitano! Do you know what they've done in Africa? I do! I see it in my dreams!
Cara, you shouldn't have to be sorry. I'm angry about it, too. There isn't much we can do about Il Duce, but what we can do is this— Act how you think you should. They don't define you.
Capitano...
You're more than the sum of your parts. If you're anything like what your namesake is supposed to be, you're beyond that, too. Cara, I mean it. You're not them.
Y-You're right. I just... I'm sorry for bringing it up. I wish they were doing better.
War changes people, so does changing regimes. Like Giorgrio, right?
Yes... Hmm... Capitano? Can we please go read a bit? I-I need to calm myself.
Of course, Cara. Chapter 10, right?
Right!
And if the war in Europe expands, t-they'll persecute anybody who speaks up against Il Duce, a-and I... I'm sorry.
But maybe you can be a reminder of what they're supposed to be.
That's one more salvo... we should be finished soon.
A good thing, too. I've got some brand new evidence, Capitano. You're going to love it - I think we've just about wrapped up this case.
Let's blow this battle out, then.
@BATTLE
All right, what have you got now?
Tell me, Capitano, are you familiar with Desmoulins?
You mean the guy that got executed along with Georges Danton?
That's what I thought at first, but it also happens to be a French chocolate-making family.

Fields.MenuText: So... he killed Danton?
Which would mean...
What does this have to do with the Coeur?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm getting to that, Capitano. Trust me on this when I say that it's important we know about this local chocolateer.
It means that it not only narrows us down to one person, but Desmoulins is a French name. So, if you put two and two together...
Pahahaha! No, no, Capitano. Like I said, the only coincidence here is the name sharing. On the subject of suspects, though, I've got a good idea who it is now.
Right. And where in France is this chocolateering family located?
Very good, Capitano! This particular chocolateer comes originally from Paris... but their main headquarters is currently in Strasbourg.
Well, that sounds familiar.
The soldier who was reported to be eating this chocolates was also spotted having a badge, a golden one. The cooks didn't give me any more info, but I think I've got a hunch.
... And? Are you really going to make me wait?
I'll need just a bit more evidence before I go confronting them, but I think know where to get that. It involves talking with the people in the engine room...
What are we waiting for!? Let's go!
Hehehe! It's so nice to see you excited, Capitano. I agree, though, let's get going!
I recently spoke with one of the cooks who was on duty that day. One of the delegation members during that time ate chocolate - from a Desmoulins box.
Huh, they really keep this place in good condition... Hopefully Cara will be back soon.
Speak of me and I'll appear!

Fields.MenuText: That smile... you've found out something!
You know how cute that smile is?
Now I'm smiling, too.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed I have, Capitano. I know I say it often, but I think you're really going to love this one. A-Am I smiling, also? Hopefully not too wide.
C-Capitano, stop! You're going to make me blush... I only smile like this when I'm really excited. I have good reason to be, and soon you'll be, too.
It's a good day for smiling, Capitano. This mystery is as good as solved. I've got some important pieces of information that I just got. Y-You've got a good smile.
Your smile's infectious, but I can't wait any longer! Well, let me hear it; what did you find?
I found out that our mystery patron was spotted down here on the same day that they ate, but that several engineers also saw that same person in the mess hall.
We've got him now...
It gets better. You see that box of chocolates? It was specifically addressed to our ship's dock. It was a gift from somebody over in Strasbourg.
So it's settled. Shall we?
Ah, ah, ah! Not yet, Capitano. I still have some evidence to present. You see, Pepe's whole betraying ordeal? You remember where it took place?
Alsace. So Strasbourg is suggesting... Whoever this person is... but wait, why would a turncoat sabotage another turncoat?
There are two reasons in my head, both are playing the same song, but one of them has a Stradivarius. The question you should be asking isn't why they would turn on each other, Capitano.
What should I be asking, then? Where are their morals?
Good one, but no. What you should be asking, Capitano, is what choice did they have to make?
A choice...?
Yes, a choice. I'll explain that next.
Let's head up to the bridge, then. We shouldn't be saying all of this in the engine room.
Sounds like a plan. The bridge is empty right about now, anyway.
... I'm getting the feeling it'll be filled up before too long.
Oh, come now, Capitano. We're in safe waters and have coastline artillery! What are the chances of an attack now?
@BATTLE
They sent it, and it had the name of our culprit addressed on it.
It's always most violent before the dawn, huh?
Morganas don't sleep. At least, I don't think they do.
But, as for the rest, let's give them a nap in the water.
@BATTLE
So, we're going to confront him now?
We're going to have him come to us, Capitano. The bridge and mess hall are full.

Fields.MenuText: Shouldn't we tell Pepe or Christoph?
Why?
A detective usually puts on a grand show for that kind of thing.

Fields.DialogueText: No, we can resolve this peacefully. Besides, I'll be smoking again if I have to listen to Pepe moan about problems. This is better this way, Capitano. Trust me. I've got this all figured out.

Because, Capitano. You told me, you shouldn't say the truth immediately. You need to build up for it, and be courteous. I'm giving our suspect courtesy. Of course, I'm still going to tell them the truth.
I'm not a detective, Capitano. I'm a Belle and a soldier, first. It's all about harmony, for me at least. Right now, what matters is getting to the heart of the problem, and we're about to.
I trust you, Cara. Let's solve this.
Grazie, Capitano. You may come in!
Good morning. What's all this about?
Henri. Good to see you again. Could you please take the Coeur out, just so that I can see it?
What are you talking about? I haven't found Pepe's badge, either.
Of course you didn't. You can't find something that was never lost. Something that was taken.
What..?
I know that Desmoulins sent you a package of chocolate the other day, which you ate alone in the mess hall.
So? I like chocolates.
Martine shares your last name, Henri. Ironically, you both share the last name of Faucon.
What are you—
You hated and still hate Pepe. I'm willing to bet he holds your sister's life over your head like a pair of keys. So, you complied, and got a position. Then, to get back at Pepe, you stole the Coeur.
You knew how Christoph operated and how unlikeable Pepe was. If he lost that badge, he would've been in disgrace.
... Heh. I can't believe it.
If you'd like, I could fill in the holes. There's a big one.
I took a look at the ship's ledger, too. That box? It's from a woman named Martine.
Leutnant Faucon, formerly of the Marine Nationale, implicated in what one might call an act of sedition against the French Republic with one Joseph "Pepe" Poigny.
You would get your revenge on Pepe. In the end, you made the mistake of showing off your gains. Ledgers, all of them, linking you.
But you weren't an eager traitor, were you? Pepe threatened the life of someone you care for... perhaps Martine? Your sister, maybe?
That's what this note was about, si? "Be proud of yourself! Remember M.?"
I can't prove it, but I suspect Pepe wanted you to be... happier to be here. In the presence of the SS. So this was a reminder of what you had to lose if you weren't.
Well, I can think of one obvious exception.
So you were responsible.
Oui. You've found me out. Pepe is a rat bastard, and I wanted to see Christoph at least chew him out.
So you admit it. Where's the Coeur?
Here, take it.
What's the detail that I missed?
Martine isn't my sister. She's my wife - and she's Jewish. If I didn't agree to Pepe's terms, he would've... he would have found a way to make her disappear.
That's lower than low.
You can report me to Christoph if you both want. I don't care anymore. I betrayed my country, I deserve to die.
In the mess hall, you looked at your stolen goods, ate the chocolate from Martine, and then hid in plain sight. Though that scar on your back gives you away if you know to look for it.
Martine gave it to me. It's a long story, but I'm a dead man, anyway.
You're not, Henri.
What?
I said you're not. We have the Coeur back, and we're going to give it to Pepe. You are dismissed, that's all we needed.
I was the one who did it! Stealing a badge like that, you know it was me, why aren't you—
I said you're dismissed, Henri. We all make mistakes. You can't take back what you did in Alsace, but perhaps... well, perhaps fate will give you the chance to balance out your sins one day.
I... .... Capitaine, Mademoiselle Carabiniere. Excuse me. ... Sorry.
That's life for you.

Fields.MenuText: I can't express how proud I am of you.
Oh, my heart.
Henri... Cara, you did the right thing.

Fields.DialogueText: Hehe. Thank you, Capitano. Most of that other evidence I managed to find out from Christoph. It was only a matter of putting two and two together. Still... I feel bad for Henri. He had no choice.
It... stings. I now know that people don't just turn their backs for any silly reason sometimes. It's... more complex than that. Fortunately, though, it all ended peacefully, and that's what matters.
A situation like that is unwinnable. Your country, or your love? Henri picked his love, and... I can't blame him for doing so. Pepe is human garbage. Thank you, Capitano, you helped me so much.
A tangled web, like a scheme from Professor Moriarty. You unraveled this case, Cara. I'm glad to help a detective.
I didn't do it for the crime, Capitano. I did it because I wanted to get peace back on this ship. Let's go give this back to Pepe—Huh? Capitano, people are shouting.
And I think I know why. Cara, I... I'm still in shock. What you did today is one of the most impressive things I've ever seen.
All in a days work, Capitano. Hmhm! Let's get these Morganas out of the way, and then we can read the rest of Styles!
@BATTLE
As to this, no one will know but me, the Captain, and you. You're dismissed—the badge was found.
La Spezia. Dead ahead. It's about time we've arrived.
They aren't making it easy for us, that's for sure.
Would it be war if it were easy?
No it wouldn't, but I think I've got a way to make this battle easier. Are you up for it, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: What am I, Watson?
Only if I can launch the salvos this time.
Does it involve bum rushing them again?

Fields.DialogueText: You'd make a fine Watson, Capitano. Don't let anybody tell you that you wouldn't. Unlike Holmes and Watson, we're equal. Now are you with me?
If you launch the salvos, I get to charge forward. It's a fair trade off, don't you think? You've gotten a lot better at reading me, Capitano.
How did you guess!? Sometimes you have to make an entrance, and being the vanguard is really fun. There's a certain flamboyant-ness to it, you know? How about it, Capitano?
Wouldn't have it any other way. Let's get this done!
@BATTLE
Well, Herr Christoph. I hope you've had an instructive stay.
Quite! You and Carabiniere have been most gracious hosts. You even found Pepe's badge! Therefore, a reward is in order.
That's my personal recipe for sacher torte - my thanks for the consistently wonderful meals we were served.
Thank you so much, Christoph. I was glad to have helped. Hopefully, Pepe's all right now.
I had to admonish him a bit, but he's learned his lesson. Well! I will report back to Reichsführer to say that our mission was a success and that our allies have wonderful Belles. Tata for now!
Take care, Herr Christoph!
This is... incredibly tempting.
What? The recipe?
That's the thing, Capitano... I didn't earn it alone. The crew and you helped me solve the case.
... You did good, Cara.
So did you, Capitano! Hmph!
Ah... I wasn't expecting a hug, but... this is nice.
When we make this, we're going to need to make it in bulk.
That's really not necessary.
I insist! Please, take this!
A recipe card?
Si. The Germans know their desserts, Capitano.
Well, you certainly earned the treat, if we have the ingredients.
Even at port? What in the sam hell are the other Belles doing!?
That's life for you. La pazienza e la virtu dei forti. Have a little patience, Capitano.
On the double! I'd like to try out some new maneuvers I saw in Styles.
Just so long as you don't start calling yourself Poirot, I think we'll be fine.
@BATTLE
It feels good to finally sip cola again. Perfect way to round out this expedition.
Isn't it nice? We finished the rest of Styles, too. It was just as good as the first time.
I didn't expect Alfred to be all of that. Maybe I should pick up on more contextual clues next novel? That's how it goes, I guess.
Don't be so hard on yourself, Capitano. The first book is a bit confusing compared to others, and I understand if you're feeling kind of out there in terms of trying to figure it out.
True. None of these detectives became sensations overnight. It took time, effort, and searching to solve the cases; kind of like we did.
Hopefully, peace keeps itself around my halls for now. I don't want to go back to smoking anytime soon.
I promised you, I'd make sure you didn't have to do that, you know? I'm with you, Cara.
I know you are, and I thank you a lot, Capitano. I just wish it were easier. Of course, nothing in life's easy, but I just wish I didn't feel this way.
It's a long road, Cara. I don't mind going along with you on it. Sometimes, people never learn how to let it go, other times they throw it on others. You're already two steps ahead.
Like always! Hmhm... Hey, Capitano. Thank you, and not just for everything we've done, but for what you've taught me.
There's a lot of Belles, but there's only one you, Cara. Nobody can take that away from you.
"La Benemerita," "Doll," "Stuck-up," "Stickler" - Big Sis told me that's what some of the others call me.

Fields.MenuText: "Friend," "Problem Solver," and "Herself," Cara.
"Stella" and "Gioia" sound more fitting for you.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Capitano! Hahaha! You're right. I'm going to keep being myself, no matter what.
... (Did Capitano just..? G-Goodness, my heart.) A-Ahem. Those are really good terms, but I wouldn't call myself 'all that'. T-Thank you, Capitano.
Wouldn't have it any other way. If you're Poirot, I'm Marple. Let's solve these cases and protect Italy!
Pleasure's mine, you deserve it all, Cara. Can't wait to see what we'll do together next.
Looking forward to being with you every step, Capitano.
All I can say is... I'm excited.
It just takes practice.
Because of you, I'm more confident in myself and... I don't know, I feel free. I don't feel shame for being... me.
All right, let's clear these out and then see about resupplying.
For you? I've got all the patience in the world.
